learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate the underlying principles of medical imaging systems
Formulate numerical algorithms to generate medical images based on these principles.
Design and implement algorithms using programming tools like MATLAB
Critique the utility of standard imaging techniques
Assess the risks and side effects of techniques and materials used.
Determine appropriate imaging techniques for various simple clinical scenarios.
Analyse the opportunities and technical challenges of the covered imaging systems.
Synthesize information independently from diverse resources.

assessments.task_description:
This is an individual assessment and students are expected to work independently. There will be 10 short multiple choice questions online related to nuclear medicine imaging. These questions weigh 10% of the final grade. Students can attempt as many times as they like to learn the content.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students will submit a project report (as an MS Word file) and functional Matlab code for assessment. The Matlab code should be written in a way that the lecturer should be able to run it without modifications or entering any parameters. If the Matlab code does not produce the results shown in the report, students will not receive any credit for the corresponding section(s) of the report. This is an individual assessment and students are expected to work independently.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures - Medical Imaging

Radiographic Imaging (Week 1 - Week 3)

Nuclear Medicine Imaging (Week 4 - Week 5)

Ultrasound Imaging (Week 6 - Week 7)

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (Week 8 - Week 13)

Learning outcomes: L01, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures - Medical Imaging Radiographic Imaging (Week 1 - Week 3) Nuclear Medicine Imaging (Week 4 - Week 5) Ultrasound Imaging (Week 6 - Week 7) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (Week 8 - Week 13)

learning_activities.topic:
Applied Class - Medical Imaging

Applied classes will provide students with an opportunity to receive feedback from teaching staff.

Radiographic Imaging (Week 1 - Week 3)

Nuclear Medicine Imaging (Week 4 - Week 5)

Ultrasound Imaging (Week 6 - Week 7)

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (Week 8 - Week 13)

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L08
